Key Arguments: The proposed laws will infringe on freedom of speech, a cornerstone of democracy.
Policing dialogue on social media is inherently subjective and has a poor track record of identifying truth.
Government powers to regulate media narratives could lead to manipulation of public opinion to fit government agendas.
Restricting opinions can isolate individuals from criticism and debate, potentially strengthening their ideologies.
The legislation could impose an undue bureaucratic burden on online platforms, making it unworkable for some and reducing resources available to Australians.
Notable Quotes: These proposed laws, regardless of their intent, will infringe on the freedom of speech that is a cornerstone of a democratic system that we enjoy.
The arbitrator of fact and fiction can only ever be a subjective exercise and one I believe has a poor record of identifying truth in practice.
Any powers given to government, through regulations, to shape the narrative on a media platform are powers to shape the opinions of the voting public to the government's own agenda.
